definition:
Let $A$ be a square matrix (over any field ${\mathbbmss{F}}$). An entry
in $A$ is an *anti-diagonal entry* if it is on the line going from the
lower left corner of $A$ to the upper right corner. If all entries in
$A$ are zero except on the anti-diagonal, then $A$ is an *anti-diagonal
matrix*.

If $a_1, \ldots, a_n \in {\mathbbmss{F}}$, let
$$\operatorname{adiag}(a_1, \ldots, a_n) = \begin{pmatrix}
0 & 0     & 0     & 0   & a_1 \\
0 & 0     & 0     & a_2 & 0  \\
0 & 0     & a_{3} &     & 0  \\
0 & \cdot & 0     &     & 0  \\
a_n & 0   & 0     &     &  0
\end{pmatrix}.$$

### Properties of anti-diagonal matrices {#properties-of-anti-diagonal-matrices .unnumbered}

1.  If $A$ and $D$ are $n\times n$ anti-diagonal and diagonal matrices,
    respectively, then $AD, DA$ are anti-diagonal.

2.  The product of two anti-diagonal matrices is an diagonal matrix.
